q3.description: PDAs have 2 different types of language acceptance. One is acceptance by final state. Under this definition, it does not matter what hte contents of the stack might be at the end of processing the string.
q3.question: Acceptance by final state means that if the machine ends processing of the string in a final state then the string is accepted.

q4.description:
Definition: Let $M = (Q, \Sigma, \Gamma, \delta, q_0, z, F)$ be a NPDA.
Then $L(M) = \{w \in \Sigma^* | (q_0, w, z) \stackrel{*}{\vdash} (p, \lambda, u), p \in F, u \in \Gamma^*\}$.
q4.question: What is $\Gamma$?

q5.description:
Definition: Let $M = (Q, \Sigma, \Gamma, \delta, q_0, z, F)$ be a NPDA.
Then $L(M) = \{w \in \Sigma^* | (q_0, w, z) \stackrel{*}{\vdash} (p, \lambda, u), p \in F, u \in \Gamma^*\}$.
q5.question: What is $z$?

q6.description:
Definition: Let $M = (Q, \Sigma, \Gamma, \delta, q_0, z, F)$ be a NPDA.
Then $L(M) = \{w \in \Sigma^* | (q_0, w, z) \stackrel{*}{\vdash} (p, \lambda, u), p \in F, u \in \Gamma^*\}$.
q6.question: To properly interpret $(q_0, w, z) \stackrel{*}{\vdash} (p, \lambda, u),$ $p \in F, u \in \Gamma^*$, what does it mean that $q_0$ changed to $p$?
q6.answer: The machine moved from start state $q_0$ to state $p$.
choices: The machine moved from start state $q_0$ to state $p$.
The string is consumed by the machine.
The stack content is changed based on the transitions.

q7.description:
Definition: Let $M = (Q, \Sigma, \Gamma, \delta, q_0, z, F)$ be a NPDA.
Then $L(M) = \{w \in \Sigma^* | (q_0, w, z) \stackrel{*}{\vdash} (p, \lambda, u), p \in F, u \in \Gamma^*\}$.
q7.question: To properly interpret $(q_0, w, z) \stackrel{*}{\vdash} (p, \lambda, u),$ $p \in F, u \in \Gamma^*$, what does it mean that $w$ changed to $\lambda$
q7.answer: The string is consumed by the machine.
choices: The machine moved from start state $q_0$ to state $p$.
The string is consumed by the machine.
The stack content is changed based on the transitions.

q8.description:
Definition: Let $M = (Q, \Sigma, \Gamma, \delta, q_0, z, F)$ be a NPDA.
Then $L(M) = \{w \in \Sigma^* | (q_0, w, z) \stackrel{*}{\vdash} (p, \lambda, u), p \in F, u \in \Gamma^*\}$.
q8.question: To properly interpret $(q_0, w, z) \stackrel{*}{\vdash} (p, \lambda, u),$ $p \in F, u \in \Gamma^*$, what does it mean that $z$ changed to $u$
q8.answer: The stack content is changed based on the transitions.
choices: The machine moved from start state $q_0$ to state $p$.

q9.description:
Definition: Let $M = (Q, \Sigma, \Gamma, \delta, q_0, z, F)$ be a NPDA.
Then $L(M) = \{w \in \Sigma^* | (q_0, w, z) \stackrel{*}{\vdash} (p, \lambda, u), p \in F, u \in \Gamma^*\}$.
The NPDA accepts all strings that start in $q_0$ and end in a final state.
q9.question: Are the stack contents relevant if the machine ends in a final state?

q10.question: What is the language represented by the PDA?

q11.description:
$L = \{a^nb^n | n \ge 0\}, \Sigma = \{a, b\}, \Gamma = \{z,a\}$.
Let us trace the string $aaabbb$.
q11.question: Is string $aaabbb$ in the language?

q27.answer: Yes, the machine ended in a final state

q28.description:
$L = \{a^nb^n | n \ge 0\}, \Sigma = \{a, b\}, \Gamma = \{z,a\}$.
Let us trace the string $aaabbb$.
q28.question: Does the stack content affect the acceptance of the string?
q28.answer: No, in this model of acceptance we use the stack as a memory
choices: No, in this model of acceptance we use the stack as a memory

q29.question: What about the string $abab$, will it be accepted?
q29.answer: No, it is not in the language
choices: No, it is not in the language
Yes, the string has the same number of $a$ and $b$
